fr:mainmatter.html:p: We characterise the polarised evaluation order through a categorical structure where the hypothesis that composition is associative is relaxed. Duploid is the name of the structure, as a reference to Jean-Louis Loday’s duplicial algebras. The main result is a reflection \textit {Adj}\to \textit {Dupl} where \textit {Dupl} is a category of duploids and duploid functors, and \textit {Adj} is the category of adjunctions and pseudo maps of adjunctions. The result suggests that the various biases in denotational semantics: indirect, call-by-value, call-by-name… are a way of hiding the fact that composition is not always associative.

fr:title.text: Research Assistant / Associate: New Spaces Project (Fixed Term)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Research Assistant / Associate: New Spaces Project (Fixed Term)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We invite applications for a Research Assistant/Associate to join the New Spaces for Denotational Semantics project. Appointment at Research Associate level is dependent on having a PhD. Those who have submitted but not yet received their PhD will be appointed at Research Assistant level, which will be amended to Research Associate once the PhD has been awarded.

The New Spaces project aims to develop an axiomatic framework for higher-dimensional program semantics with applications to concurrency, using recent advances in category theory, type theory, domain theory, and the polarised structure of computational effects. The project will focus initially on two-dimensional generalisations of call-by-push-value, duploids, and resource modalities.

The position will involve working with Dr Jon Sterling and other project collaborators, including both PhD students and faculty. It will run initially for 24 months, with the possibility for a further 12 month extension.

The successful candidate is likely to have (or expect to be awarded soon) a PhD in computer science or a related discipline, as well as a track record of research expertise in a subset of the following topics:

html:ol.html:li: Domain-theoretic semantics of programming languages
Two-dimensional category theory and/or formal category theory
Categorical semantics of linear logic
Homotopy type theory and univalent foundations
Event structure or presheaf semantics of concurrency
Use of proof assistants such as Agda, Coq, Lean, or Isabelle

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Informal enquiries are welcome and should be directed to Dr Jon Sterling (js2878@cl.cam.ac.uk). To apply, please visit the official posting.
A project to explore the category theory of duploids and their higher-dimensional generalizations.

This is an investigation of Guillaume Munch-Maccagnoni’s theory of duploids, working in the setting of univalent foundations. Most of what we do could be done in non-univalent foundations; the purpose of univalence is to sharpen our perspective on the relationship between structure and property in duploid theory.

A category has hom sets, and is always assumed to be univalent / Rezk-complete; we use the term precategory to refer to a structure that has hom sets and a type of objects with no univalence condition.

The most basic construct of duploid theory is a deductive system, a variant on the concept of a precategory that relaxes the associativity axiom to reflect the evaluation order of execution in effectful programming languages and proof theories. In this section, we define deductive systems and develop their basic properties.

A deductive system \mathcal {D} is given by a type \mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} of “objects”, and for every pair A,B\in \mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} a set \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {D}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} of morphisms, together with cut and identity laws:

html:ol.html:li: cut: for each A,B,C\in \mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} and f\in \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {D}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g\in \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {D}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}}, a morphism f;g\in \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {D}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,C\right )\mathclose {}}.

identity: for each A\in \mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}}, a morphism 1_{A}\in \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {D}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,A\right )\mathclose {}} such that 1_{A};f = f and f;1_{B} for each f\in \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {D}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given a deductive system \mathcal {D}, we will write A\in \mathcal {D} to mean A\in \mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} and f:A\mathrel {{\vdash }_{\mathcal {D}}} B when f\in \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {D}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}}. When \mathcal {D} is clear from context, we will write \vdash instead of \mathrel {{\vdash }_{\mathcal {D}}}.
Let f:C \vdash D be a morphism in a deductive system \mathcal {D}.

html:ol.html:li: We say that f is linear when for all g:B\vdash C and h:A\vdash B, we have h;{\mathopen {}\left (g;f\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left (h;g\right )\mathclose {}};f.
We say that f is thunkable when for all g:D\vdash E and h : E\vdash F, we have f;{\mathopen {}\left (g;h\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}};h.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An object B in a deductive system \mathcal {D} is called positive when every map B\vdash C is linear; it is called negative when every map A\vdash B is thunkable.
The following are equivalent for a deductive system \mathcal {D}:

html:ol.html:li: every map is linear;
every map is thunkable;
every object is positive;
every object is negative;
the cut law is associative;
\mathcal {D} is a precategory.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Supposing that every map is linear, we must check that each f:A\vdash B is thunkable. Fixing g:B\vdash C and h:C\vdash D, we must check that f;{\mathopen {}\left (g;h\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}};h; as h is assumed linear, the equation holds. The converse holds by identical reasoning.
Clearly every object is positive if and only if every map is linear; likewise, every object is negative if and only if every map is thunkable.
Finally, when every map is both linear and thunkable, the cut law is associative — but this is exactly the condition that the deductive system give rise to a precategory.

fr:title.text: Inverses and invertibility in deductive systems

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverses and invertibility in deductive systems

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Inverses to morphisms in a deductive system need not be unique due to the general failure of associativity; therefore, we must be careful when speaking of “invertible maps” or “isomorphisms”. It happens that both linear and thunkable inverses are unique.
Let f : A \vdash B be a morphism in a deductive system \mathcal {D}. An inverse to f is defined to be a morphism g : B\vdash A such that f;g = 1_{A} and g;f = 1_{B}.
Let \mathcal {D} be a deductive system, and let f : A\vdash B be a morphism in \mathcal {D}. Then both the type of (linear, thunkable) inverses of f is a proposition.
Let f:A\vdash B be a morphism in a deductive system \mathcal {D}. We say that f is (thunkably, linearly) invertible when there exists a (thunkable, linear) inverse to f.

Let \mathcal {D} be a deductive system and let A be an object of \mathcal {D}. An upshift structure for A is defined to be a negative object \mathord {\Uparrow } A and a linear map \mathsf {force}_{A} : \mathord {\Uparrow } A\vdash A for which there exists a necessarily unique and thunkable inverse \mathsf {delay}_{A} : A\vdash \mathord {\Uparrow } A.

Let \mathcal {D} be a deductive system and let A be an object of \mathcal {D}. A downshift structure for A is defined to be a positive object \mathord {\Downarrow } A and a thunkable map \mathsf {wrap}_{A} : A\vdash \mathord {\Downarrow } A for which there exists a necessarily unique and linear inverse \mathsf {unwrap}_{A} : \mathord {\Downarrow } A\vdash A.

fr:title.text: The univalence condition for deductive systems

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The univalence condition for deductive systems

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A deductive system \mathcal {D} is called positively univalent when for any positive A\in \mathcal {D}, the type of positive objects B\in \mathcal {D} equipped with a thunkably invertible thunkable map f:B\vdash A is contractible.

A deductive system \mathcal {D} is called negatively univalent when for any negative A\in \mathcal {D}, the type of negative objects B\in \mathcal {D} equipped with a linearly invertible linear map f:B\vdash A is contractible.
A deductive system is called univalent when it is both positively univalent and negatively univalent.

fr:title.text: Uniqueness of shifts in univalent deductive systems

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Uniqueness of shifts in univalent deductive systems

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let P\in \mathcal {D} be a positive object in a negatively univalent deductive system; then the type of upshift structures on P is a proposition. In this case, we may refer to the property of P having an upshift.

Let f_0:M_0\vdash P and f_1:M_1\vdash P be two upshift structures on P, whose inverse delay maps are written d_0,d_1 respectively. We wish to identify the pairs {\mathopen {}\left (M_0,f_0\right )\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left (M_1,f_1\right )\mathclose {}}.

All four maps f_0,f_1,d_0,d_1 are linear: the forcing maps are linear by definition, and the delay maps are linear because they come from a positive object. Thus we have a linearly invertible linear map f_1;d_0 : M_1\vdash M_0; because \mathcal {D} is assumed negatively univalent, we may identify the pairs {\mathopen {}\left (M_0,1_{M_0} : M_0\vdash M_0\right )\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left (M_1,{\mathopen {}\left (f_1;d_0 : M_1\vdash M_0\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}. Precomposing with f_0 : M_0\vdash P in both sides, we have {\mathopen {}\left (M_0,f_0\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left (M_1,f_1\right )\mathclose {}} because d_0 is linear as a map out of a positive object.

Let N\in \mathcal {D} be a negative object in a positively univalent deductive system; then the type of downshift structures on N is a proposition. In this case, we may refer to the property of N having a downshift.

Let w_0:N\vdash P_0 and w_1:N\vdash P_1 be two downshift structures on N, whose inverse unwrapping maps are written u_0,u_1 respectively. We wish to identity {\mathopen {}\left (P_0,w_0\right )\mathclose {}} with {\mathopen {}\left (P_1,w_1\right )\mathclose {}}.

All four maps w_0,w_1,u_0,u_1 are thunkable: the wrapping maps are thunkable by definition, and the unwrapping maps are thunkable because they are valued in a negative object. Thus we have a thunkably invertible thunkable map u_1;w_0 : P_1\vdash P_0; because \mathcal {D} is assumed positively univalent, we may identify the pairs {\mathopen {}\left (P_0,1_{P_0}:P_0\vdash P_0\right )\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left (P_1, {\mathopen {}\left (u_1;w_0:P_1\vdash P_0\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}. Taking inverses and precomposing with w_0 on both sides, we have {\mathopen {}\left (P_0,w_0\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left (P_1,w_1\right )\mathclose {}} using the fact that w_0 is thunkable and inverse to u_0.
An object A in a deductive system is called polarized when it is either positive or negative.
A deductive system \mathcal {D} is called a preduploid when every object A\in \mathcal {D} is polarized.
A preduploid \mathcal {D} is called a duploid when it satisfies the following properties:

html:ol.html:li: the preduploid \mathcal {D} is univalent;
every positive object of \mathcal {D} has an upshift;
every negative object of \mathcal {D} has a downshift.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Equivalently, we can define a duploid to be a univalent preduploid such that every object is merely equipped with both an upshift and a downshift.

To see that the main definition implies our alternative definition, let A be an object of the preduploid; because we are proving that A is merely equipped with both an upshift and a downshift, we may proceed by cases on the polarization of A.

html:ol.html:li: If A is positive, we choose the identity map A\vdash A for the downshift and we use our assumption to deduce that A has an upshift.
If A is negative, we choose the identity map A\vdash A for the upshift and we use our assumption to deduce that A has a downshift.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Conversely, assume that every object is merely equipped with both an upshift and a downshift. That a positive object P has an upshift is a proposition, so we can use our assumption that P merely has an upshift. That a negative object N has a downshift is likewise a proposition, so we can use our assumption that N merely has a downshift.
